name: Student Taught Courses (StuCo): Neuroscience for Non-Majors
base_name: Student Taught Courses (StuCo): Neuroscience for Non-Majors
long_desc: Anybody can learn neuroscience. Whether you are an artist, scientist, writer, philosopher, musician, or anyone else, as long as you are interested in how the mind works, this course is for you. Understanding the processes that determine your consciousness, emotions, reality, perceptions, and the only way you have ever experienced life is immensely powerful and meaningful. This introduction to neuroscience is tailored to accommodate for ANY background. The course will teach fundamental neuroscience concepts. It will also provide an overview of areas in current neuroscience research learning and memory, neurodegenerative and psychiatric diseases, etc., experimental techniques used in neuroscience research, and neuroscience applications in a variety of different fields ranging from science fiction writing to philosophy to artificial intelligence. Instead of a midterm or final exam, there will be two projects that encourage you to use your individual creativity and the unique backgrounds and sets of skills you bring to the course.

custom_fields.goals: By the end of the course, students are expected to have a solid foundation of fundamental neuroscience concepts, be able to think creatively about future directions for neuroscience research, and understand the applications of neuroscience in a wide variety of fields.
custom_fields.key_topics: Fundamentals in cellular and systems neuroscience, overview of various current research topics, psychiatric diseases, science fiction, artificial intelligence, philosophy of neuroscience.
custom_fields.assessment_structure: Students will be required to answer one weekly homework question about the subject of the most recent lecture, or complete a reading (for the science fiction unit).There will be two projects, one at mid semester and one at finals. Use your unique skill set to apply what you learned in the course and put together a project. It can be a science fiction story, a piece of artwork, an essay, a powerpoint presentation, code you write, or something else! The requirements are to apply something(s) you learned in the course, and to use your imagination! There will be a "gallery walk" on the day each project is due, where you can see what your classmates have created.
custom_fields.relevance: Anybody can learn neuroscience. Whether you are an artist, scientist, writer, philosopher, musician, or anyone else, as long as you are interested in how the mind works, this course is for you. Understanding how the brain works is applicable to a wide variety of fields, and I want to make science feel more accessible to everybody.
custom_fields.learning_resources: I will upload PowerPoint slides, relevant/helpful readings and videos, breakdowns and summaries of the research papers we'll cover, and my own notes for the course on Canvas.
custom_fields.extra_time_commitment: Complete the homework and projects outside of class.
